awd_titl_txt: Opportunities in Manufacturing of Advanced Materials for Second Career Seeking Students
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program supports the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need.  Over the five-year award, this project at the Batten College of Engineering and Technology at Old Dominion University (ODU) will fund 60 scholarships to students, in groups of 6-8 students who are pursuing undergraduate and graduate degrees in engineering. The project will include recruitment of second career seeking students interested in a concentration in manufacturing of advanced materials. In addition to scholarships, the program will include a hands-on, project-based curriculum with opportunities to conduct interdisciplinary research projects in advanced manufacturing areas.  Co -curricular activities will include regular seminars, mentoring opportunities, and participation in professional societies and conferences for S-STEM scholars. This S-STEM project aims to create a pipeline for well-trained second career students entering engineering professions with focus on manufacturing of advanced materials.

The project will focus on understanding the factors that affect academic success of engineering students at ODU. The combination of interventions will improve self-efficacy beliefs and outcome expectations among second career seeking students. Faculty from the Batten College of Engineering and Technology will collaborate with researchers in the Department of Psychology at ODU to study barriers, supports and resources that affect agility, academic success, recruitment, retention, and degree attainment of engineering students. The project will extend the methodology previously developed at ODU for understanding the differential experiences of groups of students as they transition along their careers paths. From the educational research point of view, the project will study the transition process for second career seeking students as an educational psychology research problem, identifying the critical barriers and the key driving factors (i.e. support and resources) that facilitate a successful transition to a new career. When acted upon, this knowledge may lead to improvements in the success rate for second career seeking students in engineering programs at ODU and nationwide. Therefore, the inclusion of second career seeking students at ODU will contribute to the national effort to engage wider groups of academically talented, hardworking students with financial need in STEM careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) S-STEM program enabled the Batten College of Engineering and Technology (BCET) at Old Dominion University (ODU) to support and empower second career-seeking students pursuing undergraduate and graduate degrees in engineering with a focus on manufacturing advanced materials. Over the six-year duration of the program, this initiative awarded a total of 63 annual scholarships to academically talented, financially needy students, opening pathways to STEM careers for a diverse and motivated population.

Intellectual Merit
This project advanced our understanding of the barriers and supports that influence second career-seeking (SCS) students’ success in engineering education. Collaborating with psychology faculty, we identified factors such as self-efficacy, resilience, and outcome expectations that shape the unique academic journeys of SCS students. Insights from this work can inform strategies to improve recruitment, retention, and degree attainment for similar populations nationwide.

The NSF S-STEM program also fostered innovative learning opportunities by integrating hands-on, project-based experiences into the curriculum. Students were introduced to cutting-edge research topics in advanced materials manufacturing, including 3D printing of polymers and composites, automated fiber placement, machine learning, and characterization of lightweight materials for compression molding and urban air mobility vehicles. These activities bridged classroom concepts with real-world applications, preparing students for careers in high-demand areas of engineering.

Broader Impacts
This project had transformative impacts on both the participants and the broader engineering community:

  1. Enhanced Access to Engineering Education: The program supported a wide range of non-traditional students, including veterans, individuals with disabilities (15% of participants), former technicians, cooks, welders, waiters, landscapers, and construction workers. Over 70% of the students were second career seekers, bringing unique perspectives and experiences that enriched the academic environment. Additionally, 40% of the scholarship recipients were women, 20% were veterans, 37% were African-American, and 15% were Hispanic or Pacific Islander students.
  2. Pipeline Development: The program emphasized creating a pipeline of skilled graduates entering the STEM workforce or pursuing advanced degrees. Of the 63 students supported, 34 have graduated, including 26 with BS degrees, 4 with MS degrees, and 4 with PhDs. Notably, 28 participants were transfer students from other universities, community colleges, or second-degree programs.
  3. Career Outcomes: S-STEM graduates have joined organizations such as the U.S. Air Force, Navy, and NASA research centers (4 graduates); marine and civil engineering firms (9 graduates); and mechanical engineering companies (7 graduates). Additionally, 8 graduates pursued advanced degrees at ODU and other institutions, contributing to the academic and professional advancement of the field.

Key Activities and Accomplishments during NSF S-STEM program duration:

  1. Educational Seminars and Workshops: Over 60 seminars and workshops were conducted throughout the program, featuring guest speakers from leading universities across the U.S., international visitors, and experts from industry and government research labs, including the Navy, NASA, and the Department of Defense. These sessions provided students with insights into cutting-edge research and career opportunities in advanced materials manufacturing.
  2. Mentorship and Research Achievements: Students participated in mentorship programs that supported their professional and academic growth, resulting in the presentation and publication of over 20 research products. S-STEM scholars received numerous awards, including two consecutive SAMPE Bridge Competition awards (2023-2024), Student Poster Awards from SAMPE, and Best Paper awards from the American Society for Composites.
  3. Research Opportunities: The program provided robust research experiences in topics like 3D printing, fiber composites, and dynamic mechanical characterization of ceramic materials. Students actively participated in cutting-edge projects, such as machine learning for material analysis and propeller characterization for urban air mobility vehicles.
  4. National Competitions: S-STEM scholars participated in various national competitions focused on design and manufacturing with advanced materials, drone design, robotics, and autonomous systems, showcasing their innovation and technical skills.
  5. Student Symposiums: S-STEM recipients honed their technical presentation skills through biannual MAM student symposiums. These events enabled students to share research progress, engage in collaborative discussions, and develop essential communication and project-based learning skills.

The S-STEM MAM program was designed to provide tailored support to second career-seeking students by addressing their unique needs in curriculum, research, outreach, and professional training. The program’s focus on professional development empowered students to transition successfully into engineering careers. Over its duration, the S-STEM program effectively provided the resources, training, and confidence necessary for SCS students to excel in STEM fields.

The success of this initiative demonstrates the value of investing in non-traditional students to expand the STEM workforce. By supporting and preparing second career-seeking students, the program has contributed to the national effort to build a diverse, skilled, and innovative engineering workforce. This NSF S-STEM project highlights how targeted support, innovative curricula, and research opportunities can create transformative outcomes for students and the engineering profession. As a result, it serves as a model for fostering diversity, equity, and excellence in STEM education.

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2025
Modified by: Oleksandr Kravchenko
